summary: This paper presents a participatory design methodology for developing assistive robots tailored to real-world user needs, particularly in healthcare settings. Engineers should care because it emphasizes iterative co-design with stakeholders, leading to more effective and user-friendly robotic systems.
key_contribution: A comprehensive participatory design approach that integrates iterative in-situ co-design for developing assistive robots in healthcare environments.
problem_description: The traditional design of assistive robots often fails to meet the practical needs of users due to a disconnect between technology and real-world application contexts.

method.approach: The methodology consists of three phases: observation and inspiration, in-situ co-design through prototyping, and longitudinal evaluation. Stakeholders collaborate with researchers using low-fidelity prototypes to define functionality and refine system behavior.
algorithm_steps: 1. Conduct initial observations and interviews to understand user needs.
2. Develop a low-fidelity prototype based on initial insights.
3. Engage stakeholders in co-design sessions to define functionalities and interactions.
4. Iterate on the prototype based on user feedback.
5. Deploy the prototype in a real-world setting for evaluation.
6. Collect user feedback and performance data during the deployment.
7. Refine the design based on longitudinal evaluation results.
method.input: User requirements, environmental context, low-fidelity prototypes.
method.output: Refined assistive robot design and functionality tailored to user needs.
key_parameters: evaluation_duration: 10 months total (8 months design + 2 months evaluation)

datasets: User feedback from healthcare staff and patients during the 2-month deployment period.
metrics: Usability, user adoption patterns, satisfaction levels.
baselines: Traditional design methodologies without participatory design.
benchmarks.improvement: Identified five distinct user personas reflecting varying levels of adoption and satisfaction.

use_this_when: Designing assistive robots for healthcare settings.
Engaging with stakeholders who have limited experience with robotic technologies.
Seeking to align robotic functionalities with real-world user needs.
dont_use_when: The user group has extensive prior experience with robotic systems.
Rapid prototyping is required without stakeholder involvement.
The project timeline does not allow for iterative feedback.

implementation_guide.pseudocode_hint: for each user in stakeholders: gather feedback; refine prototype; repeat until satisfactory.
gotchas: Ensure stakeholders are engaged throughout the process to avoid misalignment.
Be prepared for continuous iteration based on user feedback.
Manage expectations regarding the capabilities of the robotic system.

prerequisites: Knowledge of user experience research methods
limitations: May require significant time investment for iterative design
Dependent on stakeholder availability and engagement
Performance issues may arise during initial deployments
open_questions: How can this methodology be adapted for other domains beyond healthcare?
What are the long-term impacts of assistive robots on user behavior and workflow?
